III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation 1: Facility did not provide appropriate medical care to
Youth S relative to nose bleeds and blood pressure.
Allegation 2: Facility lacks behavioral health care policies and
procedures.
Investigation ALLEGATION 1
Interviews:
I interviewed Midnight Team Leader by phone on 3/22/24. She
was hired as a direct care worker and promoted to a Team Leader
on 1/14/24. She denied she is a nurse, physician, or other trained
medical professional. She said she works in Myriam and DeRoy
Halls from 11pm – 7:30am, and occasionally works in other
buildings and other shifts.
Midnight Team Leader said Youth S has nose bleeds that last 15
– 45 minutes. She consulted with Vista Maria’s nurse for one of
the nosebleeds and the nurse instructed Complainant to hold a
cold wet towel over Youth S’ nose, which Complainant did. Team
Leader said she has also consulted the nurse about the youth’s
swollen feet and a nurse told her the medical team was aware and
there was nothing they could do about it. Team Leader feels the
medical staff should take the youth’s symptoms more seriously.
I notified Youth S’s Foster Care Worker that I was assigned to
investigate the allegation. She expressed no licensing concerns.
I interviewed Youth S jointly with Government Worker 1. She said
she has frequent nosebleeds, which she believes are caused by a
lack of humidity. Youth S said when her nose bleeds, staff apply
ice and cold towels to it, then a nurse sees her and asks
questions. Asked about her swollen feet, Youth S stated, “I may
have high blood pressure…It runs in my family. The nurse told
2

me to soak my feet in Epson salt.” Youth S confirmed that in
addition to nurses, she spoke to her primary physician about her
nosebleeds.
I interviewed Nurse jointly with Government Worker 1. She was
aware that Youth S has nosebleeds and when she is notified and
present, she responds in person. Whether Nurse responds to
Youth S in person or via telephone triage, she said she instructs
staff to put ice over the bridge of her nose to stop the bleeding.
Nurse said the youth is prescribed a saline nasal spray and gel for
the nosebleeds.
Nurse is also aware Youth S’ blood pressure is sometimes high
and that she has swollen feet. Most recently on 4/1/24, she said
Youth S was seen by Vista Maria’s medical doctor for blood
pressure and pain in her feet. Nurse said possible causes for the
pain in her feet were/are related to wearing shoes that were too
small and carrying excess body weight. It was recommended
Youth S lose weight and exercise to increase the circulation in her
feet.
Documents reviewed:
I reviewed nursing telephone triage notes on 2/29/24 and 3/4/24
instructing staff how to respond to Youth S’ nosebleeds.
I reviewed medical notes showing Youth S was seen by a nurse
and doctor on 3/4/24. The note for her doctor’s visit on 4/1/24 was
not yet completed according to the nurse.
ALLEGATION 2
Interviews:
Counter to the allegations made, Midnight Team Leader said Vista
Maria does have policies and procedures instructing staff on ways
to respond to youths who engage in self-harmful behaviors,
express suicidal ideation, gestures and attempts. Upon interview
Midnight Team Leader was aware of multiple interventions to
prevent suicide and self-harm including, but not limited to, clearing
the youth’s bedroom of harmful objects, increasing staff proximity
and level of supervision, preventing active self-harm by physically
removing harmful items from a youth and transporting the youth to
a hospital for a psychiatric crisis assessment if needed. The issue
was Team Leader believes Vista Maria should develop a new
policy to eliminate self-harm by prohibiting all small, sharp and
metal objects such as staples, safety pins, tacks, paper clips,
pens, pencils, screws, plastic, strings, glass windows and glass
3

nail polish and anything else a youth could ingest or scratch
against her skin.
Documents reviewed:
Suicide Prevention Policy
Suicide Prevention Work Instructions
Emergency Psychiatric Care Policy
Emergency Psychiatric Care Work Instructions
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
Analysis ALLEGATION 1
Medical records as well as Youth P and Nurse 1 indicated Youth P
is receiving routine and timely medical care for nosebleeds and
swollen feet/ankles.
ALLEGATION 2
The licensing rule requires the facility to establish and follow
written policies and procedures addressing behavioral health care.
In reviewing the policies and work instructions pertaining to
behavioral health care, I confirmed written policies and procedures
are established and no changes are necessary or recommended.
Complainant’s suggestion to eliminate all small objects from each
building that could be ingested or used to scratch the skin is not
realistic.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth S self-harms and was given razors by unidentified staff.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth P resides in Myriam Hall. In early February 2024, Midnight
Team Leader said Youth P cut her thighs with a razor and then
4

swallowed the razor. Team Leader assumed staff must have
provided Youth P with a razor to shave. She said Youth P was
treated at the hospital and returned to Vista Maria. Three weeks
later, Team Leader assumed Youth P swallowed another razor
which, she also assumed was provided to her by staff to complete
hygiene. Youth P was treated again at the hospital. Team Leader
assumed Youth P was on heightened staff supervision when she
obtained the second razor and believes a staff at Vista Maria is at
fault for providing her a razor.
I notified Youth P’s Foster Care Worker that I was assigned to
investigate the allegation. She expressed no additional concerns.
I interviewed Youth P jointly with Government Worker 1. She has
been at the facility for nine months. Prior to being placed at Vista
Maria, Youth P said she swallowed razor blades and glass at least
five other times. Youth P said no staff at Vista Maria provided her
with a razor. Rather, on 2/2/24, she stole a small wooden pencil
sharpener from school and brought it back to Deroy Hall. That
night after showering in the bathroom, she said she snapped the
pencil sharpener open and ingested two square ½” blades that
were inside. Youth P said she swallowed the blades sitting alone
on the toilet with the door closed while an unidentified staff person
was monitoring her outside the bathroom. At that time, she said
she was not on “observations” or any other heightened level of
staff supervision. Youth P denied the blades hurt going down.
But shortly after, she experienced stomach pain and coughed
blood into a napkin. That is when Youth S informed an
unidentified staff what she had done, and Vista Maria transported
her to a hospital. “I was suicidal,” she explained. Asked what it
means to be suicidal, Youth P said it means she wants to kill
herself and has or is in the process of devising a plan.
When Youth P returned to Vista Maria after swallowing razors on
2/2/24, she said she was placed on “observations” and 1:1
staffing, but gradually earned her way off of “observations.”
Youth P also denied Vista Maria staff provided her with a razor on
3/4/24. Rather that day on 3/4/24, while not under heightened
staff supervision, she said she stole two needles from a sewing kit
stored in the recreation cabinet and stole a Bic razor from the
unlocked hygiene closet without anyone noticing. She took the
needles and razor into the bathroom, snapped open the
disposable razor, removed the blade and swallowed both needles
and the blade.
5

I interviewed Team Leader 1 jointly with Government Worker 1
and Rights Officer present. She has worked at the facility for eight
years. About six months ago, she said the building was cleared of
disposable razors in anticipation of admitting higher acuity youth.
Team Leader said electric razors are provided and denied the
building currently carries or provides disposable razors to the
youths.
I interviewed Team Leader 2 jointly with Government Worker 1
and Rights Officer present via Teams. She said she worked in the
building on 2/2/24 and 3/4/24 when Youth P swallowed foreign
objects. Team Leader 2 could not recall the details of each
incident. “I wouldn’t have been directly supervising the girls.
Former Staff 2 made me aware it happened. I don’t remember
what Former Staff 2 said. Apparently, Youth P told an unidentified
staff she broke a bottle of nail polish and swallowed glass, but
there were no bottle remnants or smell left behind. No one knows
what she swallowed.”
Team Leader 2 stated youths are not searched before entering
the bathroom and the bathroom door must be shut completely for
privacy purposes. She insisted “Youths are never given a Bic
razor.”
On 4/3/24 Government Worker 1 and I attempted to interview
Former Staff 2 jointly via phone conference. Former Staff 2
scheduled a phone appointment for later that day and did not
answer when called.
On 4/3/24, Rights Officer reported the video in Myriam Hall was
only maintained for 21 days and thus, there is no footage to view
that may show Youth P entering the hygiene closet on 3/4/24.
Tour Observations:
I observed the recreation cabinet, hygiene closet and youth
bathroom in DeRoy Hall. There were electric razors, but no
disposable ones in the closet. The hygiene closet is usually
locked but was unlocked at the time I observed it because a staff
was in the process of stocking it. The recreation cabinet itself
does not lock but is located inside a locked area of the building.
Documents reviewed:
I reviewed the Client Observation policy and work instructions.
They do not include staff supervising youths on the toilet. There is
no policy that prohibits pencil sharpeners in the school or needles
in sewing kits.
6

I reviewed the Back to Basics – Guidelines, Expectations and Rules
for Campus-Wide Vista Maria Staff related to supervising youth in
the bathroom. The guidelines indicate staff should properly
supervise clients while in the bathroom. Staff must maintain a
position inside the bathroom if two or more clients are present.
There was no reliable document to review that identified what
level of staff supervision Youth P was on at any given point in
history, specifically on the day of 2/2/24 and 3/4/24 prior to her
swallowing foreign objects.
The charter school on Vista Maria’s campus called Clara B Ford is
not run by Vista Maria and does not specifically prohibit items
such as pencil sharpeners.
An incident report dated 2/2/24 at 8pm indicates during a suicide
risk assessment conducted in DeRoy Hall, Youth P admitted
cutting her left forearm and both inner thighs with a razor blade,
then swallowing the razor blade in the bathroom. Youth P was
transported to the hospital.
I reviewed a medical report from Beaumont Hospital emergency
room that indicated Youth P was seen on 2/2/24 for a suicide
attempt. The physician indicated patient presented after allegedly
swallowing razor blades from a pencil sharpener. She had
multiple superficial lacerations to her wrist and anterior thighs.
There was no oral injury, but x-ray confirmed 2 small metallic
appearing objects near the gastric region consistent with the
history of alleged ingestion.
An incident report dated 3/4/24 at 8:47pm indicates Youth P said
she cut her wrist, thighs and swallowed two razor blades and
needles in the bathroom. Youth P said she broke her personal
shaver in the bathroom to get the razor blades and took the
needles off a teacher’s desk.
I reviewed a medical report from Garden City Hospital emergency
room indicating Youth P was seen on 3/4/24 for suicide attempt,
swallowing foreign body. Chest x-ray showed two linear foreign
bodies in the stomach measuring 1.5 cm and 2.6 cm. Treating
physician indicated Youth P presented after swallowing pins and
razor blade as stated by patient. Abdominal and chest x-ray show
pins…Patient states she still wants to kill herself…Notes
hallucinations of seeing her parents around her. Psych
clearances ordered. Psych and social work consulted…
Discussed case with GI children’s and they stated as long as there
7

was no razor blade noted by radiologist there is no need to
transfer patient and patient can stool them out…Patient will be
monitored until she stools out the pins. Pending discharge after
psych evaluation.
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
Analysis On 2/2/24 Youth P told a physician she swallowed two blades
from a broken pencil sharpener. An x-ray showed two small
metallic objects in her gastric region. Youth P said she took the
pencil sharpener off a teacher’s desk without permission, but what
she swallowed and where she obtained it cannot be determined.
On 3/4/2 Youth P told a physician she swallowed razor blades and
needles/pins she took off a teacher’s desk. An x-ray showed two
linear foreign bodies in her stomach. On 3/26/24 Youth P told
investigators she snuck a disposable razor out of the hygiene
closet and took two needles from a sewing kit. Again, what she
actually swallowed and how she obtained the items cannot be
determined.
Youth P intentionally did not let staff know her plans to swallow
foreign objects prior to doing it and denied that any of the items
she swallowed were provided to her by staff. Rather she admitted
she planned and took these items from unauthorized areas and/or
without permission with the intention of ingesting them later when
alone on the toilet in the bathroom.
The Client Observation policy and work instructions do not include
staff supervising youths on the toilet. There is no policy that
prohibits pencil sharpeners in the school or needles in sewing kits.
Youth P confirmed that staff were supervising her outside of the
bathroom according to policy each time she swallowed foreign
objects. There is no evidence staff failed to provide appropriate
supervision.
CONSULTATION
To better track a youth’s supervision needs, I recommended to the
Quality Assurance Director that clinical staff begin maintaining a
running document of the date, time, type of precaution/supervision
youths are placed on, and the reason, as well as the date, time
and reason the youth was removed from that type or level of
supervision/precaution.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
8

Rule Code Behavior management
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4157
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies and
Description procedures that describe the institution’s behavior management
system. The policies and procedures shall be reviewed annually
and updated as needed. These shall be available to all residents,
their families, and referring agencies.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Facility lacks behavior management policies and procedures.
Investigation Interview:
Midnight Team Leader acknowledged Vista Maria does indeed
have written behavior management policies and procedures.
However, she said in her opinion, the physical restraint moves
taught by current behavior management system (Crisis Prevention
Institute - CPI) “are not as effective” as other restraint moves
taught by other models in other facilities. After licensing rules
prohibited behavior management rooms in November 2022,
Midnight Team Leader believes the facility needs to use a different
behavior management model that teaches more physical restraint
moves than currently taught in CPI.
Documents reviewed:
Behavior Management Policy
Behavior Management Work Instructions
Non-violent Crisis Intervention (CPI Handbook)
Analysis The licensing rule requires the facility to establish and follow
written policies and procedures that describe the institution’s
behavior management system. The facility has a behavior
management policy and work instructions, and uses CPI, a model
approved by DCWL. Mandating a different model or requiring
additional restraint moves is beyond the scope of DCWL and not
recommended at this time.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
9

Rule Code Staff to resident ratio
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (3) The ratio formula for direct care workers shall correspond with
Description the institution’s purpose and the needs of the residents and shall
assure the continual safety, protection, and direct care and
supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Facility runs a staffing ratio of 1:8
Investigation Interview:
In terms of running a ratio of 1:8, Midnight Team Leader stated
this applied to sleeping hours on the midnight shift. However, she
believes the ratio of staff to residents during sleeping hours should
be higher than 1:8. During waking hours, she confirmed they run a
1:3 ratio which is consistent with their program statement.
Document reviewed:
I reviewed the facility’s program statement which indicates a 1:3
staff to resident ratio during waking hours and 1:10 staff to
resident ratio during sleeping hours.
Analysis A 1:8 staff to resident ratio during sleeping hours is compliant with
the facility’s program statement and this licensing rule.
CONSULTATION
I encouraged Complainant to express her opinions and ideas for
changes internally to her supervisor and managers at Vista Maria.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
10

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
